docs.lead_paragraph: One way to cut government spending is to stop reimbursing contractors for the cost of pensions and other retirement benefits.

headline.seo: Dear Committee: Main St. Says Look at Pensions
headline.main: Dear Committee: Main Street Says Look at Pensions
headline.print_headline: Dear Committee: Main Street Says Look at Pensions

docs.abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Fair Game column contends one way to cut government spending is to stop reimbursing defense contractors for the cost of pensions and other retirement benefits; maintains over 10 years, such a move could save estimated $30 billion; contends this practice is not only quaint, it is an outlier.
docs.snippet: One way to cut government spending is to stop reimbursing contractors for the cost of pensions and other retirement benefits.

docs.lead_paragraph: It really stinks, but the only way to fix the economy is to squeeze the middle class.

headline.seo: It’s Not Just About the Millionaires
headline.main: It’s Not Just About the Millionaires
headline.print_headline: It’s Not just About the Millionaires

docs.abstract: Adam Davidson It's the Economy column argues that the solution the United States deficit problem is to have the middle class give up some benefits and pay more in taxes.
docs.snippet: It really stinks, but the only way to fix the economy is to squeeze the middle class.

docs.lead_paragraph: LAST year I had to have a minor biopsy. Every time I went in for an appointment, I had to fill out a form requiring my name, address, insurance information, emergency contact person, vaccination history, previous surgical history and current medical problems, medications and allergies. I must have done it four times in just three days. Then, after my procedure, I received bills -- and, even more annoying, statements of charges that said they weren't bills -- almost daily, from the hospital, the surgeon, the primary care doctor, the insurance company. Imagine that repeated millions of times daily and you have one of the biggest money wasters in our health care system. Administration accounts for roughly 14 percent of what the United States spends on health care, or about $360 billion per year. About half of all administrative costs -- $163 billion in 2009 -- are borne by Medicare, Medicaid and insurance companies. The other half pays for the legions employed by doctors and hospitals to fill out billing forms, keep records, apply for credentials and perform the myriad other administrative functions associated with health care.
docs.abstract: Ezekiel J Emanuel Op-Ed column asserts that billions of dollars are wasted on needless paperwork and payment processing in the American health care and insurance systems; argues that streamlining and digitizing the billing process would create the most savings. Drawing (M)/

docs.lead_paragraph: Pfizer is offering to give discounts on Lipitor to pharmacists who keep filling prescriptions with the name-brand drug once generic competition begins.

headline.main: Plan Would Delay Sales of Generic for Lipitor
headline.print_headline: Plan Would Delay Sales Of Generic For Lipitor

docs.abstract: Pfizer is asking drugstores to block prescriptions for generic version of its Lipitor starting in December, when company loses its patent for the cholesterol drug and generic competition starts; Pfizer is offering to give discounts on Lipitor to pharmacists who keep filling prescriptions with brand-name drug.
docs.snippet: Pfizer is offering to give discounts on Lipitor to pharmacists who keep filling prescriptions with the name-brand drug once generic competition begins.
